articles.headline: Digital Coach Perched Right in Your Pocket
articles.snippet: Companies have started to introduce some intriguing sports devices that analyze movement using sensors.
articles.abstract: Companies have started to introduce some intriguing sports devices that analyze movement using sensors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tech world’s current obsession is with wearables — the idea being that you can stuff all manner of technology into increasingly tiny packages. So far, much of the attention has been on watches and glasses. But the same teeny sensors and smartphone brains that power those devices have other applications, too — for instance, in a new wave of smart sports equipment.

articles.headline: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
articles.snippet: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
articles.abstract: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee released Wednesday concluded that the attack 16 months ago that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, could have been prevented, singling out the State Department for criticism for its failure to bolster security in response to intelligence warnings about a growing security crisis around the city.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Facebook Revamps Ads to Compete With Google
articles.snippet: Small businesses can use tools on Facebook to track customers from ad to website, and target audiences more precisely.
articles.abstract: Small businesses can use tools on Facebook to track customers from ad to website, and target audiences more precisely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last June, Facebook released a tracking pixel, a snippet of code that allows advertisers to track customers who come to their websites from Facebook ads. For Amy Norman, co-chief executive officer of Little Passports, the pixel was a game-changer.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Seek Curbs on Trading Commodities
articles.snippet: A Senate hearing comes as concerns grow that the huge commodities holdings of investment banks allow them to manipulate prices for essentials like oil and electricity.
articles.abstract: A Senate hearing comes as concerns grow that the huge commodities holdings of investment banks allow them to manipulate prices for essentials like oil and electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers pressed the Federal Reserve on Wednesday to act more forcefully, and quickly, to limit banks’ involvement in the commodities business, which has been blamed for inflating prices on everyday items like electricity and canned beverages.

articles.headline: Financier Says He’s Guilty of Everything but a Crime
articles.snippet: Florian Homm, a former fund manager from Germany who faces extradition to the United States on security fraud, has willfully documented his rise and fall.
articles.abstract: Florian Homm, a former fund manager from Germany who faces extradition to the United States on security fraud, has willfully documented his rise and fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Defense lawyers almost always give the same advice to clients facing charges: Don’t say a word in public. That admonishment comes too late for Florian Homm.

articles.headline: Romance Novelist Wins Big Valentine
articles.snippet: Sylvia Day, the author of the “Crossfire” series of romance novels, will receive a substantial sum from St. Martin’s Press for her next two books.
articles.abstract: Sylvia Day, the author of the “Crossfire” series of romance novels, will receive a substantial sum from St. Martin’s Press for her next two books.
articles.lead_paragraph: St. Martin’s Press is making a very big bet that Americans are still hot and heavy for romance novels.

articles.headline: After Crisis, Iceland Holds a Tight Grip on Its Banks
articles.snippet: Iceland is a living experiment in what can happen when a country forces its financial firms to go under, rather than bailing them out.
articles.abstract: Iceland is a living experiment in what can happen when a country forces its financial firms to go under, rather than bailing them out.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — An angular glass building on the waterfront here used to be the headquarters of a banking giant with operations in Europe, North America and the Middle East.

articles.headline: Federal Contracts Plunge, Squeezing Private Companies
articles.snippet: In the 2013 fiscal year, total federal contracts fell by $58 billion, or roughly 11 percent, the steepest decline in at least a decade.
articles.abstract: In the 2013 fiscal year, total federal contracts fell by $58 billion, or roughly 11 percent, the steepest decline in at least a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big business of Washington — federal contract work — is losing some steam.

articles.headline: U.S. to Expand Rules Limiting Use of Profiling by Federal Agents
articles.snippet: The new rules will prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said.
articles.abstract: The new rules will prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department will significantly expand its definition of racial profiling to prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Chinese Activists Test New Leader and Are Crushed
articles.snippet: An anti-corruption group was heartened when China’s new president, Xi Jinping, came to power in 2012. Since then, their ideals have collided with a harsh reality.
articles.abstract: An anti-corruption group was heartened when China’s new president, Xi Jinping, came to power in 2012. Since then, their ideals have collided with a harsh reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The 20 or so activists gathered at an isolated guesthouse on the outskirts of the capital, leaving their cellphones behind to avoid detection by the police. China’s first leadership change in a decade was fast approaching, and the group saw an opening for a movement to fight injustice and official corruption.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Obama’s Path From Critic to Overseer of Spying
articles.snippet: In 2007, Barack Obama described a surveillance state run amok. He is now the leader of a surveillance state that some of his own advisers think has gotten out of control.
articles.abstract: In 2007, Barack Obama described a surveillance state run amok. He is now the leader of a surveillance state that some of his own advisers think has gotten out of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a young lawmaker defining himself as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama visited a center for scholars in August 2007 to give a speech on terrorism. He described a surveillance state run amok and vowed to rein it in. “That means no more illegal wiretapping of American citizens,” he declared. “No more national security letters to spy on citizens who are not suspected of a crime.”
